HUD TAKES AWAY CONTROL OF A HOMELESS PROGRAM FROM NEW YORK CITY 

  (sw) 
 By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   NEW YORK _ Andrew Cuomo, secretary of housing and urban
development, said on Tuesday that HUD would take direct control of
a program that provides $60 million in federal money for services
for the homeless in New York City, because, he said, the
administration of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani could not be trusted to
distribute the money fairly.

   Cuomo, a supporter of Hillary Rodham Clinton in the New York
Senate race, said his decision was in response to a recent federal
court decision that found that the Giuliani administration had
improperly blocked an AIDS service organization from receiving
federal money, in retaliation for the organization's frequent
criticism of the mayor.

   ``We cannot allow federal funds to be politicized,'' Cuomo said,
in announcing at a State Assembly hearing in Manhattan that city
officials would no longer be responsible for awarding grants under
HUD's Homeless Continuum of Care program. ``We're going to remove
the city of New York from a position of control of those federal
funds.''

   Giuliani swiftly retaliated, accusing Cuomo of playing politics
with the nation's programs for the homeless. Giuliani is Mrs.
Clinton's likely Republican opponent in the Senate race, and her
campaign manager is Bill De Blasio, who until recently was theregional HUD director in New York.

   ``There is no question that Andrew Cuomo runs a major league
political operation,'' the mayor said at his daily news conference.
``He wants to take over the handing out of money directly, which is
otherwise described as political patronage.''

   Cuomo has made no secret of his political allegiance, and he
told reporters after Tuesday's Assembly hearing that ``Hillary
Rodham Clinton will be the next senator from New York.'' But in his
testimony and in subsequent interviews, he insisted that the
decision to take away the city's control of the program for the
homeless was in response to the recent court decision and other
complaints.

   On Nov. 12, Judge Allen G. Schwartz of Federal District Court in
Manhattan ruled that city officials had penalized an AIDS service
organization, Housing Works, for its attacks on the mayor, and
lowered the group's score on a list that prioritizes the city's
needs in regard to homeless services, making it impossible for the
group to win funding.

   The Continuum of Care Program provides grants to local nonprofit
social service organizations for a variety of programs that assist
the homeless, including outreach and prevention efforts, job
training, counseling and rent subsidies. Housing Works had sought
$2.4 million for programs for homeless people with AIDS, mental
illness or drug addiction.

   The federal housing agency awards the grants each year based on
a ranking of potential projects that is developed by the city in
consultation with an advisory group of social service providers.
The city is informed beforehand how much money is available so
officials are in a position to know which projects will receive
funding as they develop the list.

   The Housing Works programs had initially received scores that
put them 30th and 33rd out of 71 New York City projects, according
to court evidence. Later the city lowered those rankings to 57th
and 60th knowing that the first 56 projects had requested a total
of $53.9 million out of a total of $54 million available for New
York City, Schwartz wrote in his decision.

   ''The Federal District Court judge says in very clear language
that the process has been politicized, that the group's criticism
of the mayor caused them to lose federal funds'' Cuomo said on
Tuesday. ``So once the federal court says the process is not
working, that the process is tainted, this department as
administrator of those funds must act.''

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   Cuomo said that his agency had received numerous complaints
since the program began in 1994 about New York City's role in
ranking projects, including a complaint last year by the Coalition
for the Homeless, another group that is frequently critical of
Giuliani. In a letter to the Coalition in July, housing officials
said the complaint appeared to be justified.

   Giuliani said that Cuomo acted too quickly because the city has
appealed the Housing Works case. ``We have learned often that cases
get overturned on appeal,'' he said. ``It happens very very
often.'' The mayor also pointed to previous allegations of
political dealing against Cuomo, including an investigator's
finding last year that housing workers were being used for
political public relations work.

   ''Unfortunately, it's quite apparent that he has brought his
politicizing of HUD to New York,'' Giuliani said. ``Now when his
representative who was the regional director of HUD has become
Hillary Clinton's campaign manager, it appears as if he is trying
to direct patronage to those people who are his political
supporters, possibly Al Gore's and others.''   

   Cuomo said he would reconsider his decision if an appeals court
overturned the ruling by Schwartz. He added the mayor's political
charges were an effort to distract people from the real issue of
the city's role in awarding federal grants. ''This has always been
a concern that a city could retaliate against homeless groups by
using the federal funds and holding them hostage,'' he said. Howard
Wolfson, the spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign, said
that she had not been informed in advance about Cuomo's plan. ``We
had no involvement in the decision and the mayor's policies speak
for itself,'' he said.
